Notes: Kirby, S. (2001). Spontaneous evolution of linguistic structure-an iterated learning model of the emergence of regularity and irregularity. IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation, 5(2), 102-110.

[Native speakers] extend inflections based on type frequency (i.e., apply the inflection used across most items in the vocabulary), while non-natives extend inflections based on token frequency (i.e., apply the inflection from the most frequent item in the vocabulary)

Non-nativesâ€™ input is skewed towards irregular types with high token frequency, and thus they are more likely extend quasiregularity when inflecting novel forms, especially when novel forms exhibit phonological similarity with existing irregulars (Cuskley et al., 2015)
agent types have a first preference for extending inflections based on phonological similarity
Results from this framework support recent theories that the relative proportion of native and non-native speakers in a population has the potential to affect the structure of language
